statement:
Let $\vartheta$ be an algebraic integer of $n$. The algebraic number
field $\mathbb{Q}(\vartheta)$ has always an integral basis of the form

$\displaystyle\omega_1 = 1,$\
$\displaystyle\omega_2 = \frac{a_{21}\!+\!\vartheta}{d_2},$\
$\displaystyle\omega_3 = \frac{a_{31}\!+\!a_{32}\vartheta\!+\!\vartheta^2}{d_3},$\
$\vdots\,\qquad\vdots\,\qquad\vdots$\
$\displaystyle\omega_n = \frac{a_{n1}\!+\!a_{n2}\vartheta\!+\ldots+\!a_{n,n-1}\vartheta^{n-2}\!+\!\vartheta^{n-1}}{d_n}$,

where the $a_{ij}$’s and $d_i$’s are rational integers such that
$$d_2\mid d_3\mid d_4\mid\ldots\mid d_n,$$ i.e.
$$d_i\mid d_{i+1}\quad \forall\, i = 2,\,3,\,\ldots,\,n\!-\!1.$$

The integral basis $\omega_1,\,\omega_2,\,\ldots,\,\omega_n$ is called a
[*canonical basis*]{} of the number field.

**Remark.** The integers $a_{ij}$ can be reduced so that for all $i$ and
$j$, $$-\frac{d_i}{2} < a_{ij} \leqq \frac{d_i}{2}.$$ Then one may speak
of an [*adjusted canonical basis*]{}. In the case of a quadratic number
field $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{d})$ with $d \equiv 1\, (\mbox{mod}\, 4)$ we
have (see the examples of ring of integers of a number field)
$$\omega_1 = 1,  \quad \omega_2 = \frac{1\!+\!\sqrt{d}}{2}.$$ The
discriminant of this basis is $d$.
